title-group.article-title: Global stability analysis for a generalized delayed SIR model with vaccination and treatment

sec.title: Introduction
Mathematical model and preliminaries
sec.p: We also assume that the disease causes death with rate c and γ is the natural recovery rate of the infected individuals.

The assumption of the concavity of the treatment function refers to the fact that the supply of the treatment drugs increases as the disease kicks off in the population until it reaches a maximum level, then the treatment drug stocks start going down due to the exhaustive consumption.

sec.title: Proposition 2.1
sec.p: The solution of (3), with initial condition (4), is positive and bounded.

sec.title: Proof
sec.p: The local existence and boundedness of the solution of (3) imply the global existence of the solution.

sec.p: Thus, the next generation matrix for system (5) is FV−1=(βf2(E0)(μ+c+γ)+T′(0)000).
To prove the existence of an endemic equilibrium, we need the following lemma.

sec.title: Lemma 3.2

sec.p: Next result shows the existence of the endemic equilibrium.

sec.title: Theorem 3.1
Proof
Local stability analysis
sec.p: In this section, we discuss the local stability of the disease-free equilibrium of system (5). We have the following result.

sec.title: Theorem 3.2
Proof
Global stability of the disease-free equilibrium
Theorem 3.3
Proof
Global stability of the endemic equilibrium
Theorem 3.4
Proof
Numerical results
sec.p: All the numerical simulations are performed using the explicit Runge–Kutta-like method (dde45) [38].

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In our analysis we showed that when the disease is endemic, in the absence of the vaccination and treatment, then there are two possible scenarios: (a) if the number of susceptible population is below the threshold S̄, then the disease can be controlled by vaccination and treatment; (b) if the susceptible population is above the threshold S̄, then the disease will persist in the population. This finding reflects the limited capability of the control measure to eradicate the disease if the population is too large.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: The authors would like to thank the anonymous reviewers for their valuable comments and suggestions which helped us to improve the quality of our work.

sec.title: Availability of data and materials
sec.p: Data sharing not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.

notes.p: All authors contributed equally to this work. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
